quotes.topic_title: Work can be fun and still valuable
quotes.text: We tend to undervalue the things we're good at.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A reminder to reassess your strengths because what feels easy to you may be your highest-leverage value.

quotes.topic_title: Work can be fun and still valuable
quotes.text: But the reality is you should go do the thing that you feel guilty to get paid for, if there's a thing like that, and do the hell out of it, right?
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for choosing work: follow the activity you enjoy so much it feels unfair, then commit fully.

quotes.topic_title: Work can be fun and still valuable
quotes.text: If you get pleasure from doing something that people want to pay you for, do it the best you can do it, as hard as you can do it.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Actionable advice to pair intrinsic motivation with market demand and then pursue mastery with intensity.

quotes.topic_title: Work can be fun and still valuable
quotes.text: Work doesn't necessarily have to be hard.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that challenges the assumption that difficulty is required for meaningful or valuable work.

quotes.topic_title: Work can be fun and still valuable
quotes.text: Sam is most known for basically inventing Google Docs with his company Writely, which was acquired by Google, and became the foundation for what is now Google Workspace, which currently has over one billion active users a month.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example and scale data point illustrating the real-world impact of Sam’s work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Sam is most known for basically inventing Google Docs with his company Writely, which was acquired by Google, and became the foundation for what is now Google Workspace, which currently has over one billion active users a month.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example and scale data point showing how a startup-originated product became a massively adopted platform.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: As you'd suspect, we had a fairly wide-ranging conversation, but the core focus was around innovation, how to think big, how to come up with original ideas, why optimism is so important and powerful, and also a ton of career advice.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Summarizes the episode’s actionable themes, highlighting optimism as a key lever for innovation and idea generation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This time of year is prime for career reflection and setting goals for professional growth.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical prompt to use seasonal cycles as a trigger for structured career planning and goal-setting.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I always like to spend this time reflecting on what I accomplished the previous year, what I hope to accomplish the next year, and whether this is the year I look for a new opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable reflection framework practitioners can apply annually to guide career decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I always like to spend this time reflecting on what I accomplished the previous year, what I hope to accomplish the next year, and whether this is the year I look for a new opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A simple annual reflection framework for evaluating progress, setting goals, and deciding whether to pursue a job change.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Teal provides you with the tools to run an amazing job search.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Reframes job hunting as an operational process you can systematize with the right tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With an AI-powered resume builder, job tracker, cover letter generator, and Chrome extension that integrates with over 40 job boards, Teal is the all-in-one platform you need to run a more streamlined and efficient job search and stand out in this competitive market.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete, tool-based workflow for making a job search more efficient and differentiated.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: There's a reason nearly 1 million people have trusted Teal to run their job search.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific adoption data point suggesting strong product-market fit and social proof.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for how much compliance work can be automated, plus a scale signal via company count.

quotes.topic_title: The first Google Doc and Writely origins
quotes.text: It was pre-cloud, so we had three file servers that we rented that were Windows machines in a data center in Texas with a sysadmin in the Philippines running them.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A concrete example of starting scrappy with minimal infrastructure—useful for practitioners who over-index on needing “modern” stacks to begin.

quotes.topic_title: The first Google Doc and Writely origins
quotes.text: And then when we moved to Google, we ported everything to Java, we moved all the data over into Bigtable. And we didn't lose anything. We never lost anybody's stuff.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Highlights a reliability bar during major migrations—successful rewrites are possible without data loss if treated as a core requirement.

quotes.topic_title: The first Google Doc and Writely origins
quotes.text: And then so that's one backend migration, and there's another one with Spanner. And then the front end has been rewritten twice as well. So it's like, is it really the same document?
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A memorable identity/continuity mental model for systems that undergo repeated rewrites: what makes an artifact “the same” over time?

quotes.topic_title: The first Google Doc and Writely origins
quotes.text: I'm like, "How?" I can make you a PDF. Now it's not the document. I can share you into it, but please don't edit it. How do you curate this?
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Surfaces a practical, counterintuitive problem of preserving digital artifacts: access and authenticity are entangled with editability and platform dependence.

quotes.topic_title: Sneaky infrastructure migration into Google
quotes.text: When we migrated in to Google, we were very sneaky about it, and we put the site into "maintenance mode" for eight hours on a Sunday, where everything was just read-only.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for reducing migration risk: schedule a limited read-only window during low-traffic time to safely cut over infrastructure.

quotes.topic_title: Sneaky infrastructure migration into Google
quotes.text: And then we migrated all the data and moved everything and brought the new system up.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A simple execution sequence for a cutover: migrate data, move services, then bring up the new system.

quotes.topic_title: Sneaky infrastructure migration into Google
quotes.text: And three days after that, Sergei was in a meeting with me and he's like, "So when are you guys going to move over to Google infrastructure?" And I got to tell them, "Oh yeah, we did it this weekend."
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Illustrates the bar for “seamless” migrations: success can look like even internal stakeholders don’t notice the change happened.

quotes.topic_title: Sneaky infrastructure migration into Google
quotes.text: Some blogger in Germany noticed that the IP address changed and that was it.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A specific example showing that the smallest external signals (like IP changes) may be the only visible evidence of a major backend migration.

quotes.topic_title: Why-not vs what-if thinking for innovation
quotes.text: So I call these why-not questions. People ask these why-not questions a lot. So a new thing pops up, and if you're not ready to receive it for some reason, you're not already half there or you don't have a problem that it solves or whatever, it's just threatening and irritating, and you come up with a why-not question.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Introduces a practical framework for recognizing defensive objections that block disruptive ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Why-not vs what-if thinking for innovation
quotes.text: We heard a bunch of these with Google Docs, with Writely, in the early days about the browser wasn't ready, people wouldn't... The whole model of the cloud was like, people aren't going to trust you to store your files. That's really weird. What if there's no connectivity? I heard the no connectivity on an airplane story 100 times from journalists. Like, "What if I'm on an airplane and I write stuff?" I'm like, "I don't know. There'll be connectivity on airplanes soon." Which there is. And those are all just why-not questions.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Concrete examples show how common “edge case” objections can be predictable and temporary, not decisive blockers.

quotes.topic_title: Why-not vs what-if thinking for innovation
quotes.text: I think the more interesting ones are the what-if questions, like, what if this does work? Just use your imagination. Think about, how far can I extend the curve? What are the implications of that?
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Offers a generative questioning method to explore upside scenarios and second-order implications.

quotes.topic_title: Why-not vs what-if thinking for innovation
quotes.text: So I have this kind of mantra now that there's just not that much of a prize for being pessimistic and right, particularly in a moment like this. It's much better to be optimistic and wrong than pessimistic and right, I think.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A contrarian heuristic for decision-making under uncertainty that encourages experimentation over defensive correctness.

quotes.topic_title: Love-hate reactions signal disruptive products
quotes.text: If you hear people saying something's a toy, that's often a really good signifier that it's actually something real and threatening, and they can't think of a better criticism for it than it's just a toy right now.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for spotting early disruptive ideas by listening for dismissive “toy” critiques.

quotes.topic_title: Love-hate reactions signal disruptive products
quotes.text: And that bifurcation of love it, hate it, is really how you have an idea of whether you have impact in what you're building.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic: polarized reactions are a signal you’re building something with real impact.

quotes.topic_title: Love-hate reactions signal disruptive products
quotes.text: If you get more of the bell curve of modern indifference and maybe mild like and mild dislike, that's an's an incremental product. That's not really disrupting anything.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that broad mild approval often indicates low disruption rather than success.

quotes.topic_title: Love-hate reactions signal disruptive products
quotes.text: But if you look at something like ChatGPT where the entire world is like, "This is amazing." Or, "This is terrible." And there's not a whole lot in between, that's a very good signifier of it being truly impactful and disruptive.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A concrete modern example illustrating the “polarization = disruption” framework in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Love-hate reactions signal disruptive products
quotes.text: So, for a long time, the haters outnumbered the people who were fans. And who cares? Whatever. It's fine. As long as you don't run out of the people who love it, that's fine.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: An execution-oriented mindset: you don’t need majority approval early—just enough passionate believers to sustain momentum.

quotes.topic_title: First-principles, experimentation, and generative AI
quotes.text: So it's expensive, it hallucinates, you can't necessarily... It's sarcastic, it's random, it doesn't do the same thing twice. Yeah, they're real, they're actual issues to solve, but I look at it and think, "Well, what if? What if we can build software around it? What if we can build more complicated programs than what we've been able to build? What if we actually have a reasoning engine that we can use to do meaningful things? What if this is really the second Industrial Revolution where, in the first one, we had a surplus of physical energy beyond just our bodies and things like water reels, and now we have a surplus of cognitive energy beyond just our brains, right?"
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Reframes generative AI’s current flaws as solvable constraints and proposes a “what if” lens that treats AI as a potential surplus of cognitive energy.

quotes.topic_title: First-principles, experimentation, and generative AI
quotes.text: And that's a really transformational idea. So I'm completely in that mode right now, honestly. I think that's just the right mindset for something that's obviously this disruptive, right or wrong.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Advocates adopting a deliberate “transformational” mindset when evaluating disruptive technologies before certainty is available.

quotes.topic_title: First-principles, experimentation, and generative AI
quotes.text: But once you have the what-if, right, just to pick on SpaceX for a second, right? If you have what-if of like, "If I could make payload to space cost a lot less, what if?" Okay, that's amazing. That's an amazing world. Let's see if we can work on that problem. And then now you have all the why-nots? Why not? Why isn't it as cheap as it could be? And you can start to break the problem down and think about it that way. It's a good model.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Offers a practical two-step model: start with an inspiring “what-if,” then systematically enumerate “why-nots” to decompose and attack the real constraints.

quotes.topic_title: First-principles, experimentation, and generative AI
quotes.text: Tesla is a great example. SpaceX is a great example where people are like, "That doesn't make any sense." And Elon's like, "Well, what if you could land rockets and reuse them and they get really cheap? That's pretty amazing. What if I can fix the battery problems and a car is basically a software product, right?"
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Uses Tesla and SpaceX as concrete examples of “what-if” questions that unlock non-obvious product strategies (reusability, software-first framing).

quotes.topic_title: Optimism as a deliberate product-building choice
quotes.text: It's funny, it's a choice. I'm not an optimistic person by nature. I'm just not.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Frames optimism as a deliberate, trainable strategy rather than a personality trait—useful for leaders building teams and products under uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Optimism as a deliberate product-building choice
quotes.text: I just personally feel like I've missed out on more than I've protected myself from.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A contrarian risk lens: pessimism can feel “safe” but may carry a larger hidden cost in foregone opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Optimism as a deliberate product-building choice
quotes.text: So part of that is being more optimistic, so being more willing to try stuff, and part of it is also just making it cheaper to try things.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Connects mindset to process: optimism is reinforced by lowering the cost of experimentation, a practical product-building methodology.

quotes.topic_title: Optimism as a deliberate product-building choice
quotes.text: So there's always a little bit of a leap of faith. And then you want to make those as consumable as possible. You want to be able to try things out quickly and learn things and do these experiments.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for innovation: accept uncertainty, then structure work into small, fast, learnable experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Optimism as a deliberate product-building choice
quotes.text: Because stuff always is different. You're always wrong about products. That's one of my other rules is you're just always wrong. And so you have to try it. You have to put it in front of people. You have to try it yourself before you'll understand it. No one can really design products in their head completely as far as I can tell.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A blunt product-development rule that pushes teams toward prototyping and user exposure over purely theoretical planning.

quotes.topic_title: User value, laziness, and convenience wins
quotes.text: So that's one of my other root principles is just like it's all about user value. Users are lazy, right? We're all lazy. We don't really care that much at the end of the day. No one's going to do something really in their life for any other reason other than it makes their life better. Nobody cares that you're friendly or nice or the logo is pretty or whatever. They care about making their life easier. We're all cynical at heart at some level, so if you can't point at user value, significant user value, it's not going to work.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A blunt adoption principle: if you can’t clearly articulate meaningful user value, everything else (branding, niceness, marketing) is noise.

quotes.topic_title: User value, laziness, and convenience wins
quotes.text: One is, I think products almost follow these thermodynamic rules where if you add a little bit of value, your adoption goes slowly and if you add a lot of value, your adoption goes really quickly, right?
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for growth: adoption speed is proportional to the magnitude of value delivered, not just novelty.

quotes.topic_title: User value, laziness, and convenience wins
quotes.text: I think ChatGPT is a great recent example of something that was just added a ton of new value to the world and got this explosive growth, and then you see lots of other AI stuff that people are doing that's just not bad, but not great, and it's sort of kind of adding a little bit of value and slowly lumbering along, or maybe it's going to collapse under its weight.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A concrete comparison practitioners can use to calibrate whether they’re building a breakthrough (explosive adoption) or an incremental tool (slow churn-prone growth).

quotes.topic_title: User value, laziness, and convenience wins
quotes.text: But you forget all the stuff around it. The user has to hear about it, the user has to remember it in the moment. The user has to learn how to use it, they have to build the habit. That's all effort, right? Not to mention the fact that the actual use of your feature might have friction on the way in, right? It might be hard to sign up for it.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that “better feature” isn’t enough—total system friction (discovery, memory, learning, habits, signup) is the real adoption cost.

quotes.topic_title: User value, laziness, and convenience wins
quotes.text: When we did Writely at the beginning, we didn't even ask for an email address, because it was such a novel thing. We didn't want any friction at all in the onboarding process. So you could just come in and make a document and start using it without telling us anything at all about yourself. And after about two minutes of typing, if you're still there, we'd very gently just say, "Please give us your email address, no password, no anything. Just give us your email address so we can send you a URL of this document in case you care about it later. Because if you leave, we'll never know where... We'll never be able to find it again."
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A specific, replicable onboarding tactic: remove upfront signup friction and ask for credentials only after the user has experienced value.

quotes.topic_title: Disrupting Office: simplicity, collaboration, innovator’s dilemma
quotes.text: Because there's a very high transactional cost, the buyers would always make this decision like, "Do I want the thing with 1,000 features or the thing with 995 features? I don't know what those last five are, but I might as well have all of them."
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for why incumbents accumulate feature bloat when switching/install costs are high—and how that shapes buyer behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Disrupting Office: simplicity, collaboration, innovator’s dilemma
quotes.text: So we made this trade-off, we're like, "Look, we're easy to use, we're zero install, you don't have to ever deal with it, it's super convenient. Plus you get this one new feature that's really, really useful, which is collaborating with each other and not having to send attachments around the old file servers, but we're going to take away most of the features, because we don't care about them that much."
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Actionable product strategy: win by removing features to deliver a step-change in convenience plus one killer differentiator (real-time collaboration).

quotes.topic_title: Disrupting Office: simplicity, collaboration, innovator’s dilemma
quotes.text: And we took away a little bit more than we should have. In the early days, we'd get all these complaints about people who wanted word count, which I thought was a really weird... I thought that was going to be way at the end of the list.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A concrete example of how teams can mispredict “small” must-have features—useful for prioritization and early adopter feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: Disrupting Office: simplicity, collaboration, innovator’s dilemma
quotes.text: We just chipped away from the bottom, like the innovator's dilemma.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A memorable encapsulation of disruptive strategy: enter where the incumbent doesn’t care, then expand upward over time.

quotes.topic_title: Disrupting Office: simplicity, collaboration, innovator’s dilemma
quotes.text: We took a bunch of market share, but they kept all the money basically.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that user share and profit capture can diverge—important for business model and competitive strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Early Google Docs: accidental collaboration and hard problems
quotes.text: The fact that you could collaborate on them was kind of an accident.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Highlights how valuable product breakthroughs can emerge unintentionally from early prototypes before features are “properly” designed.

quotes.topic_title: Early Google Docs: accidental collaboration and hard problems
quotes.text: We hadn't built the thing that would lock somebody out yet. So there was just like, "Here's a document, you can edit these two things." Which we, A, immediately realized was really cool. We could both work in the same document at the same time. And then, B, realized, "Oh, crap, we're colliding with each other, because there's no presence or anything like that. And there's no collision detection or anything like that."
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A concrete example of shipping value first and discovering the real hard problems (presence/collisions) only after users experience the magic.

quotes.topic_title: Early Google Docs: accidental collaboration and hard problems
quotes.text: The interesting thing too with that is, I think if we'd gotten it in the other order, we might not have done it.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A counterintuitive sequencing lesson: seeing the payoff early can be necessary to justify tackling a multi-year technical challenge.

quotes.topic_title: Early Google Docs: accidental collaboration and hard problems
quotes.text: Where we got really lucky that we saw the what if part, that we saw how cool a document in a browser that you could collaborate on would be, because if we understood how hard the collaboration piece would've been first without understanding that value, we might've been like, "Eh, it's not worth it. It's going to be so hard to solve that problem. It's probably not a useful app."
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A memorable “what if vs why not” mental model for innovation: let the compelling vision pull you through the hard engineering work.

quotes.topic_title: Early Google Docs: accidental collaboration and hard problems
quotes.text: Firefox would do a blank paragraph with a singleton BR tag, and IE would do it with an open closed paragraph tag. And so even the tree doesn't match.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A specific technical data point illustrating why collaboration/merge logic was unusually difficult due to inconsistent browser DOM representations.

quotes.topic_title: Internal resistance and balancing rigidity with feedback
quotes.text: The first week I was at Google, an executive there refused to give me hardware, because he thought that Google was an app company not a... It was a search company, not an app company.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A concrete example of how internal resistance can show up immediately and block progress in surprisingly basic ways.

quotes.topic_title: Internal resistance and balancing rigidity with feedback
quotes.text: And I had to threaten to either sue him or haul him in front of Eric Schmidt, because I had a contract and I had contracted earnouts.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: Shows that sometimes innovation survival depends on escalation paths and structural/legal leverage, not just product merit.

quotes.topic_title: Internal resistance and balancing rigidity with feedback
quotes.text: So that was another one of these interesting lessons of sometimes the opposition is enormous.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A blunt reminder to anticipate and plan for outsized internal pushback when pursuing novel bets.

quotes.topic_title: Internal resistance and balancing rigidity with feedback
quotes.text: I think the hard stuff is this mindset of being open in the right ways and understanding that some kinds of pushback are good pushback. Some are bad.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A practical mental model: classify feedback/pushback rather than treating all resistance as equally valid or invalid.

quotes.topic_title: Internal resistance and balancing rigidity with feedback
quotes.text: I always think that product builders and entrepreneurs, you have this really hard problem of you have to be very rigid about your mission. I know where I'm going. I know what my mission is, and I'm going to go there because the world doesn't care, it's going to push back. But you also have to be really flexible about feedback. You're probably aren't going to be right about a bunch of it. And so you have to blend these two things together somehow.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A memorable framework for execution: hold mission constant while iterating aggressively based on feedback signals.

quotes.topic_title: From early traction to future of interactive documents
quotes.text: We decided to go just advertise on Google. At the time, 37signals was the cool company. And we're like, "That looks cool. We'll just be some engineers and we'll have a little subscription SaaS business thing and chill out. So let's see what it costs to acquire customers. So let's go advertise on Google and see how much it costs to get people to sort of show up, and then we'll figure out if we have a subscription business or not."
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A practical early-traction method: use paid acquisition as a fast experiment to estimate CAC and validate a viable business model.

quotes.topic_title: From early traction to future of interactive documents
quotes.text: But when we got noticed, we really got noticed. There was just this period where we were the hot thing for a couple months, where every VC wanted to talk to us and everyone's trying to figure it out.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A concrete example of how attention can spike suddenly once a product signals a new platform shift—useful for timing fundraising and hiring.

quotes.topic_title: From early traction to future of interactive documents
quotes.text: We spent a bunch of energy on offline, which was miserable, which never turned out to matter that much.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning about over-investing in “must-have” features that feel important early but don’t drive long-term value.

quotes.topic_title: From early traction to future of interactive documents
quotes.text: I think it's kind of funny now that we're spending billions of dollars on GPUs to emulate wind pulp and ink pressed by metal type. We're building linear documents that are fixed, that are static.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A memorable critique framing today’s software as recreating outdated mediums instead of rethinking the artifact for AI-native interactivity.

quotes.topic_title: From early traction to future of interactive documents
quotes.text: I think we're going to feel the same way about intention and interactivity in our products very soon. If I can't tell something what my intent is and have it configure itself in an intelligent way, have it converse with me, whether that's a device or a piece of GUI UX somewhere, I think it's going to feel anachronistic. It's going to feel really weird.
quotes.speaker: Sam Schillace
quotes.context: A forward-looking product principle: intent-aware, conversational interfaces will become the baseline expectation, making static UX feel “broken.”
